title.native: 劇場版 Fate/stay night UNLIMITED BLADE WORKS
title.romaji: Fate/stay night Movie: UNLIMITED BLADE WORKS

description:
This is the adaptation of the 2nd route of the popular visual novel: Fate/Stay Night. In this route, Tohsaka Rin will be the major female character. Revelations about Shirou and his destiny will be made.

(Source: AnimeNfo)
synonyms: Gekijouban Fate/Stay Night: Unlimited Blade Works

node.description:
__Headquarters:__ Tokyo, Japan

__[Website](http://typemoon.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/tmitterofficial)__

__Introduction:__
Type-Moon is a Japanese game company was founded by artist [Takashi Takeuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/99054/Takashi-Takeuchi) and writer [Kinoko Nasu](https://anilist.co/staff/98250/Kinoko-Nasu), who were also schoolmates. The names "TYPE-MOON" and "Notes." come from one of their early works, Notes..

__History:__
Originally formed as a Doujin Soft in 2000 and created the popular visual novel Tsukihime, but turned into a Commercial Organization on January 30, 2004 and in the same year, they released their PC-based eroge visual novel game Fate/stay night, which is their most well known title.

__[The BAMBOO BROOM (Blog)](http://www.remus.dti.ne.jp/~takeucto/)__

A Japanese author best known for writing the visual novels Tsukihime and Fate/stay night. Renowned for a unique style of storytelling and prose, Nasu is amongst the most prominent visual novelists in Japan. 

Together with high school classmate and friend, [Takeuchi Takashi](https://anilist.co/staff/99054/Takashi-Takeuchi), Nasu formed [TYPE-MOON](https://anilist.co/staff/97582) in 2000, originally as a doujin group to create the visual novel Tsukihime. It soon gained immense popularity, much of which is attributed to Nasu's unique style of storytelling. A sequel to Tsukihime, Kagetsu Tohya, was released on August 2001. 

54563 Kinokonasu is named after him

__[The BAMBOO BROOM (Blog)](http://www.remus.dti.ne.jp/~takeucto/)__

Takashi Takeuchi is a Japanese artist, noted as the co-founder of Japanese visual novel and anime development and production enterprise [TYPE-MOON](https://anilist.co/staff/97582), and for his illustrations on TYPE-MOON's visual novels, Tsukihime and Fate/stay night.

__[Website](http://tainakasachi.net) | [Blog](https://ameblo.jp/tainakasachi/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/tainakasachi) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/sachitainaka/) | [Youtube](http://www.youtube.com/user/tainakasachi0430)__

A Japanese singer who is best known for her vocals in the opening songs of the anime version of Fate/stay night, and her amazing voice range (3 octaves), as shown in the intro of “Saikō no Kataomoi”. She states that she was singing by a river, when she was suddenly able to sing extremely high notes.

[Website](http://www.kenjikawai.com/index_e.html) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%B7%9D%E4%BA%95%E6%86%B2%E6%AC%A1)

After dropping out of a nuclear engineering program at Tokai University, Kawai Kenji began studying music at Shobi Music Academy. However, he dropped out after half a year. With a few friends, he created the band Muse, playing fusion rock and participating in music competitions. Through competing in such contests, the band members became technically competent to enter the music industry and decided to part ways.

After leaving Muse, Kawai Kenji began composing music for commercials in his home studio. While recording music for [Yuji Mitsuya](https://anilist.co/staff/95874/) he met music director Naoko Asari, who advised him to compose anime soundtracks. Some of his most famous anime soundtracks can be found in [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/1288/), [Ranma ½](https://anilist.co/anime/210/), [Ghost in the Shell](https://anilist.co/anime/43/), [Fate/Stay Night](https://anilist.co/anime/356/), [When They Cry](https://anilist.co/anime/934/) and more recently in [Mob Psycho 100](https://anilist.co/anime/21507/).

He has worked on several projects with the director [Mamoru Oshii](https://anilist.co/staff/99097/) and has written scores for all of Hideo Nakata's films. Kenji Kawai's music has received the Annie award and Hong Kong Film Award in 2005, for [Ghost in The Shell 2: Innocence](https://anilist.co/anime/468/) he was nominated for an Annie award.

Following his success as an anime music composer, he became involved in live action movies. He contributed music to horror films: Ring, Ring 2, Dark Water, Japanese-Polish science-fiction film Avalon and the Hong Kong film Seven Swords.

For the music found in Seven Swords and A Battle of Wits he was nominated for Best Original Film Score Awards at both the 25th and 26th Hong Kong Film Awards in 2006 and 2007.

(Source: AniDB)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/choco_kiku) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/菊地洋子)

Married to [Eiji Suganuma](https://anilist.co/staff/109167/).

_Note: Not to be confused with [Youko Kikuchi (菊地陽子)](https://anilist.co/staff/141535/), different kanji._
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/voss714) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/石原恵治)
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/voss714) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/石原恵治)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/_7265687568142)

Freelancer with a desk at [Studio Deen](https://anilist.co/studio/37/). Nakajima is strongly associated with the animated adaptations of the works of [Rumiko Takahashi](https://anilist.co/staff/96891/), having worked as an animation director on [Urusei Yatsura](https://anilist.co/anime/1293/), [Maison Ikkoku](https://anilist.co/anime/1453/) and [Ranma ½](https://anilist.co/anime/210/) also also serving as the character designer on latter.

She is married to [Tomohiro Hirata](https://anilist.co/staff/122071/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/西村博之_(イラストレーター%29)

Originating from [Ajia-do](https://anilist.co/studio/30/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/大塚舞)

Originating from [Shaft](https://anilist.co/studio/44/). Currently freelance.

Aspired to become an animator after having seen [Densetsu no Yuusha Da Garn](https://anilist.co/anime/2803/).

Originating from Eagle Nest. Currently freelance.

Tanaka first drew attention for the wild and imaginative fight sequences in Precure [Max Heart](https://anilist.co/anime/1929/) and [Splash Star](https://anilist.co/anime/1534/). Following this he expanded his scope and took up work on productions all around the industry, showing that fights aren't everything he can do. His variety on running sequences, often showing an effiminate touch, as well as the particular attention to hair, down to all little strains and often involving a hairdo having a life of its own, are some of Tanaka's most outstanding feats.

__Non-anime credits:__
~!
- Chief Animator, Animation Character Design, Storyboard, Director, Animation Director, Key Animation for "BlazBlue: Calamity Trigger (OP)" (video game, 2008)
- Key Animation for "Disgaea D2: A Brighter Darkness (OP)" (video game, 2013)
- Key Animation for "livetune adding Fukase (from SEKAI NO OWARI) 「Take Your Way」" (music video, 2013)
- Key Animation for "Rurouni Kenshin: Meiji Kenkaku Romantan Saisen (OP)" (video game, 2011)
- Key Animation for "Valkyria Chronicles III" (video game, 2011)!~

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/tak_tea3)

Animates on rare occasions.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/shinya1965)

Nowadays he's always credited with his given name in hiragana, but early in his career he was credited in all kanji.

_Note: Not to be confused with the [older animator](https://anilist.co/staff/148890/)._

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/436797162)

Married to animator [Maki Fujii](https://anilist.co/staff/101081/).
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/bob_yamamoto)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/asakonishida) | [Pixiv](https://www.pixiv.net/en/users/24387) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/西田亜沙子)

Originating from Studio Muu.


Married to fellow animator [Seiichi Nakatani](https://anilist.co/staff/107409/Seiichi-Nakatani).
He passed away from undisclosed causes in January 2020.
He passed away from undisclosed causes in January 2020.
